Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: This course taught standard lab techniques (reflux, distillation, IR, etc.) and supplemented lecture material in terms of reaction types and synthesis of products.

I learned the important techniques of TLC, distillation, recrystallization, and the synthesis processes for multiple organic compounds. I was well introduced to the basics of organic laboratory chemistry.
I learned some very interesting techniques in working in a chemistry lab.
Basic organic lab techniques that reinforced class material.
Different chemistry techniques that I can use in a lab like column chromatography, distillation, and the like. The knowledge gained was mostly from the regular orgo course.

The skills I learned in Organic Chemistry lab include lab safety, separation by extraction, purification by recrystallization, how to write scientifically and keep a lab notebook, reflux, distillation, melt-point analysis, TLC and column chromatography, how to dry an organic solution using salts, IR spectroscopy and analysis, vacuum filtration, and how to effectively work with a lab partner. The knowledge I gained through this course includes E1 and E2 reactions, acid-base chemistry, and it reinforced what I already knew about functional groups and polarity.

This course is great for developing techniques that are relevant and useful for synthesis of organic compounds. Specifically, we learned how to separate, extract, recrystallize, heat to reflux, TLC analysis, column chromatography, distill, and even take an IR spectra. The course also has a focus on safety, and teaches you how to read SDS and really understand the dangers of the compounds that you work with.
Basic organic chemistry lab things like how to perform separation, vacuum filtration, recrystallization, TLC, and IR spectra.
Learned a fair amount of new lab techniques.
I learned basic lab techniques, such as reflux, distillation, extraction, recrystallization, as well as synthesis methods.
I learned skills that are relevant to lab work in organic chemistry, and expanded on concepts I learned in lecture.

Through 222L, you learn basic chemistry lab tools that I believe would be helpful in carrying out your own basic experiments. By the end of it, I felt competent in a good number of standard practices.
I learned lots of new lab techniques

This course probably did the best job of reorienting my approach towards lab courses. I was incredibly happy to be apart of the atmosphere Professor DiMeglio created and felt comfortable and interested in the work we did.
I learned a lot about different lab techniques and developed greater independence working in the chemistry lab. I also developed writing skills in a scientific tone and format.
Learned much more about basic lab techniques, how to maximize yield
Basic lab techniques relevant for synthesis of organic compounds.
I learned basic orgo compound synthesis techniques as well as characterization techniques.
I learned how to apply what I was learning in class to actual lab techniques, which does not come easily for me at all, and I practiced a ton of lab and scientific writing skills.
I learned a lot of practical lab techniques and gained confidence in my lab abilities. It taught me to dread lab less!
I learned a great deal of practical lab skills. I learned how to carry out different types of reactions, work in a chemical lab setting, and how to synthesize various compounds.

I learned lab techniques related to organic chemistry, as well as problem-shooting techniques for when my lab was not working out. I also learned more about thought processes and experiments related to organic chemistry, and I reinforced some of the concepts I was learning in the lecture course.
Great parallel to Orgo 1. Helps put the reactions in perspective. A lot of good chemical skills to be learned in this class.
Basic organic chemistry lab skills and safety skills.
I actually really enjoyed Orgo Lab. It's definitely more laid back than gen chem lab and it does help you visualize the mechanisms a little bit better.
Basic orgo lab skills

I gained significant chemistry lab skills--many standard techniques and their theories--as well as how to work safely and effectively in the lab. My main insight I gained was to take my time in the lab so as not to make mistakes by rushing.
I learned how to do basic lab skills pretty well. I also learned how to prep for labs before I do them.
I learned a great deal about how to conduct organic chemistry lab techniques and synthesize different compounds.

This course reinforced my knowledge of organic chemistry concepts/reactions that I learned about in lecture and increased my familiarity with the apparatuses and processes used to synthesize, purify, and characterize organic compounds.
I gained a strong basis of lab methods that I will be able to continue in using in the future.
learned orgo lab techniques, working in a lab setting, using ChemDraw software. I learned more about the practical side of organic chemistry
I developed exactly what I expected and more: laboratory skills and patience

I have developed the necessary skills to carry out various reactions and at the end combine methods to arrive at the final product. Not only that but I have also learned about safety measures taken in such labs as well as cooperation in labs with lab mates. Finally I have also learned how to write notes about experiment and report it to others in a formal manner.
I was able to gain a lot of hands-on experience conducting basic organic chemistry lab techniques.

How an actual laboratory course should be run. This course is like a well oiled machine. Other courses (cough GenChem/UniPhysics) could stand to learn something from this structure. Every week the same process. Do the pre-lab. Do the lab. An occasional post-lab. Never any extraneous info.  Props to Dr. D for making an amazing course that keeps you engaged from start to finish

From CHEM222L, I gathered a plethora of knowledge pertaining to laboratory techniques and chemical reactions. Not only did I see what reactions occurred, but I learned to understand why they happened.
orgo chem lab skills
I learned a few basic lab techniques and skills and how to correctly create an experimental procedure.  Much of the knowledge necessary for the course overlaps with organic chemistry.
New chemistry laboratory skills
Pretty typical orgo lab
I learned a lot of new techniques.

I learned about multiple laboratory techniques used in chemistry research such as distillation, IR spectrometry, TLC, Seperation, among others. It was also supplementing the material i was learning in Organic Chemistry lecture.
Basic lab techniques.
I learned a ton of basic organic laboratory techniques. This course was great in preparing you to feel confident in a laboratory setting.
Organic chemistry is hard.

I learned basic lab skills relating to organic chemistry as well as some mechanisms for different reactions. I learned how to calculate different value that reveal certain characteristics about different compounds.
I learned basic laboratory techniques and basic organic chemistry.
This course gave me hands on and theoretical knowledge of Organic Chemistry techniques.

Basic skills in organic techniques such as TLC, distillation, reflux, separation with separatory and vaccuum funnels, recrystallization, column chromatography, and melt point and IR spectrum analysis.
I learned how to synthesize various products, conduct reflux experiments, use a condensation apparatus, read an IR spsectra and more
I learned how to safely handle chemicals and how to synthesize some cool compounds.
Nothing I will ever use but I had to take this class for pre med stuff.
This course was great with developing skills that will be useful for research in the future.
General techniques needed for organic chemistry both in industry and research. Pretty standard stuff.
I learned how to work in a lab setting more independently, as well as the basics of organic chemistry lab.
I learned about organic chemistry, and I learned how to use techniques in he laboratory.

I learned a lot of useful lab techniques and applications of organic chemistry concepts in the real world. I definitely learned how to perform basic experiments that are used in a variety of labs, which is very helpful for me because I intend to pursue research during my time at Yale. Through this course, I had the opportunity to see how concepts that I learned in the classroom could be applied to real life situations.
I enjoyed the diversity of hte organic techniques we learned.
I gained a strong understanding of various organic chemistry laboratory techniques that I know will be very useful to me as I continue my chemistry education.

I developed some basic lab techniques like separation, TLC, recrystallization, and IR Spectroscopy that would help if I wanted to pursue research. Learning how mechanism is tightly linked to lab synthesis was a valuable insight that I gained.
Standard lab procedure and safety regulations
I learned perseverance. I learned how to work hard and to take advantage of all the resources available to me.
Lab techniques. Additional comfort and confidence about bench work.

This lab was very helpful in learning important organic chemistry technique. I feel like it was a very robust introduction to basics. I feel as if the skills I learned in this class were very helpful and useful for my future courses and labs.
I learned a lot of helpful chemistry lab techniques and concepts, such as distillation, extraction, separation, TLC, IR, etc.
Acquired basic laboratory skills needed for organic chemistry lab.

This lab course will teach you the fundamentals and critical techniques needed in an organic chemical lab, help you understand core principles like extraction, isolation, purification, synthesis and various forms of analysis. The class is structured so that you actually understand the significance of various reagents and steps. It was a good supplement to the lecture course.
I learned basic organic chemistry lab techniques and gained familiarity with different laboratory equipment/glassware.
I lernt a lot of lab skills, diffrent chemicals and safety protocols.
Learned many lab techniques and about different reactions and syntheses.

I learned many fundamental chemistry lab techniques including separation, chromatography, purification, recrystallization, and distillation, and I applied these techniques in subsequent labs. I learned how to operate in lab on my own (with no lab partner) and be confident in my skills and knowledge. I learned how to write an experimental plan to prepare for all experiments. I learned how to use IR and melting point equipment, and how to interpret an IR spectra

Most of the experiments are a bit more thrilling and less time consuming than Gen Chem lab. Allowing the students to dive right into the day's experiment was nice because the EP assignments forced the students to be prepared. I learned the value of conciseness, how to analyze the reasoning behind each step of a procedure (i.e. what does adding NaCl do?), and how to work independently.

I learned and understood many of the techniques needed for this kind of organic chemistry. The lab also helped me understand the ways certain compounds are synthesized and the mechanisms behind each reaction.

I learned a lot in this introductory organic lab course. I learned techniques such as crystallization, reflux, TLC, liquid chromatography, among others. I also learned how to handle IR spectra machines.

This course was better than general chemistry laboratory by a long shot, it was less stressful in-class and Dr. DiMeglio was so much more thoughtful and kinder than the previous gen chem professor. Reactions were fairly enjoyable to do - synthesis reactions, learning your way through different laboratory equipment, IR - more basic organic chemistry I material; supplemental to what is learned in organic chemistry classes (e.g. arrow pushing) - different from gen chem in the sense that there were only 2-3 quizzes instead of weekly quizzes; no formal pre-lab lecture; only 2 lab reports that comprised of information from several previous experiments

I learned a lot of important techniques that anyone who does experiments or research in organic chemistry needs to know (ex: how to use a separatory funnel, heat a reaction under reflux, perform distillation, perform TLC, obtain and analyze an IR spectrum, etc).
Basic laboratory skills
I developed clear knowledge of chemical synthesis and analysis. Also a proper knowledge to record data for chemical compounds in an organized manner.
A good basis of procedures and processes in a typical organic chemistry laboratory (and a chemistry laboratory in general)
Many lab techniques: vacuum filtration, TLC, column chromatography, spectroscopy, distillation, purification, and many others.
I learned the basics of how to use a lot of different lab equipment and how to do organic synthesis.
222L definitely taught me many chemistry lab concepts that I feel will be useful in further chemistry studies. The format of the class let me grow as an independent chemist.
basic organic chemistry laboratory skills

I learned basic techniques in organic chemistry laboratory, such as synthesis, reflux, distillation, infrared spectroscopy, and melt point analysis. I also learned how these techniques can be used to learn more about structures and mechanisms of organic compounds.
I also learned how to handle organic compounds safely, and how/ why they should be handled differently than inorganic compounds.
Organic chemistry lab skills, and more advanced skills.
I learned how to perform experiments in organic chemistry. I learned proper lab safety and handling of chemicals. I also learned how to analyze and write up my results.
I built upon basic knowledge learned in the lecture course to learn techniques and applications of organic chemistry that helped me further understand organic chemistry.

Became familiar with many of the popular organic lab techniques, including separation/extraction, filtration, distillation, conducting reactions at reflux, melting point instruments, IR spectroscopy, etc.
I learned how to use different equipment.
I learned different techniques used in organic chemistry to synthesize compounds and test for purity.

I learned many new lab techniques that are necessary to know in an organic chemistry lab, such as vacuum filtration, using a separatory funnel, TLC, and using an IR spectrometer. I also learned about different organic chemistry reactions, such as SN2 and SN1 reactions.

I learned how to use standard organic lab equipment, and how to communicate, clean up, and operate safely in the lab. I also learned how to synthesize, purify, and analyze some basic compounds. I learned how to prepare an experimental plan and keep an organized lab notebook. I also learned how euphoric you feel when you obtain really pure crystals.
Honed basic laboratory skills and put into practice some synthesis reactions we had learned in class.
Basic Orgo lab techniques and lab etiquette.
I learned how to think analytically about what occurs under different experimental conditions and how to troubleshoot experiments gone wrong.
I developed the ability to perform a number of purification and synthesis techniques necessary in the field of organic chemistry. I also learned about Yale's science writing expectations.
I learned a lot about performing various experiments in the labs and general knowledge about lab problem solving.
How to use lab skills to observe chemical reactions in a lab setting
I learned how to use lab equipment in order to properly conduct experiments.
I learned how to perform basic but useful laboratory techniques in organic chemistry.
Organic Chemistry Lab skills and report writing skills.
So much about cool orgo lab techniques
I learned organic lab skills.

Lab procedures from a typical orgo 1 course including separation by extraction, vacuum filtration, gravity filtration, TLC, column chromatography, distillation, reflux, taking/reading IR spectra, recrystallization, synthesis, lab safety, using chemdraw to draw molecules, and scientific writing (for lab reports).
I gained experience in the laboratory, as well as confidence.
Learned and reviewed many basic organic chemistry laboratory techniques.
More in-depth laboratory skills for chemistry.
Some of the skills used were the knowledge about polarity, chirality, and different reactions to observe how they actually occur in real life.
Mainly laboratory skills such as extraction, IR Spectrum analysis, separation, TLC etc.
This course taught me a lot about how to conduct experiments and why reactions proceed the way they do.
I developed comfort and confidence in performing basic organic chemistry lab techniques.
I learned techniques used in a organic chemistry, such as recrystallization, extraction, and qualifying compounds based on melting point and NMR Spec.
Lots of chemistry intuition.
I learned a lot of lab techniques for basic organic chemistry procedures, as well as a lot of basic safety techniques to be used in the lab.
Great class, I learned a lot about organic chemistry. I learned about the importance of learning through doing.
I further developed my laboratory skills and learned how to better prepare for lab. I learned basic organic chemistry skills, reactions, and lab protocol.
Reflux, distillation, synthesis. The whole shabang! Oh and how to freeze your hands off with acetone.
I learned a lot about different chemical reactions and how to perform them best, as if to mimic what would happen in a real chemistry lab.
This lab course taught me a variety of skills and safety precautions necessary for any future wet lab. I also learned how to use several lab equipment such as IR machines and TLC chambers.
The course is fun and low-stress but also effective in teaching the material it seeks to cover.

I wish that the theoretical topics and mechanisms learned in lab somewhat lined up with what we were learning in lecture. Also, I did a lot of work for this class. Lab should be more than half a credit.
I loved this course! No weaknesses to be improved upon.
Great teaching assistants and professor made the class wonderful.

This lab was so much better than gen chem in terms of work. Preparing EPs helped understand what was expected of students in the labs and eased the process. Students were expected to prepare and know what to do during lab days, but TAs were very helpful in explaining needed details and ensuring set ups were correct. The outcomes and percent yields in lab did not matter, which made students more relaxed and provided a better learning environment.

This course was very strong. For the first several labs, we learned valuable lab skills, and for the last few, we applied these skills to synthesis reactions. I do not see any way in particular that this course can be improved.

Strengths: The course is structured very well. Dr. D understands that this is many peoples' first time working with organic reagents and using these techniques, so you are not graded on yield. You are also not overwhelmed with many techniques, and get a chance to really practice them and feel comfortable doing them. The course is nothing like gen chem lab, and neither is the instructor: the course is not overwhelmingly long, and often gets out around 3:30; there are only 3 quizzes and 2 lab reports that are very manageable; you have more freedom to work at your own pace and you do the experiments yourself; the instruct is a kind angel who actually wants to know her students and support them and teach them.

Weaknesses: The grading of the course is very dependent on how strict of a grader your TA is and your performance on like 1 quiz. The quiz only has 5 questions so if you mess 2 up like I did, you get a 60% and it impacts your grade pretty significantly. The grading needs to be more balanced.
This course was great because it wasn't too time consuming and the labs were engaging

Parts of the EP felt redundant and a waste of time. They were also graded pretty harshly. The PLAs were also graded harshly and didn't really seem important to understanding how to do organic lab procedures.
The course is great, because each student is able to work in their own hood, and only collaborate if a partner if they wish to do so.

Some of the strengths of this course are the quality of the TAs, who are very helpful in lab and answer the questions we may have. Also, Dr. DiMeglio always checks in with every student during lab, so every student feels like they are cared for and feels that the professor and TAs want them to do well and understand the material of the course.

Strengths-engaging TA's and professor, 
Weakness-subject material could be slightly repetitive at times, the odd structure of assigned and submitted work

This course is extremely well-structured, with thorough explanations and guidelines and expectations stated. The course packet is an excellent resource. Grading could definitely be more consolidated among TAs, because even though scaling will be done, I think it would be less stressful to be given a particularly harsh TA. I also think that EPs should be graded for completion and there should be more post-lab assignments to understand what mistakes not to make. I think more instructions could be given about the techniques.

It's tough to receive feedback on whether or not you're doing the procedures correctly. I don't think grading harshly by % yield or something like that is a good idea, but 0it was unclear to me if the class was supposed to be a way of showing us what the chemistry we discuss in lecture looks like in practice, or if we were actually supposed to be getting better at the lab techniques themselves. Either is fine, but clarity early in the semester might help guide what we should be spending time focusing on in our studying.

I think this course was constructed to reduce student stress, which I hugely appreciated. Things like being able to play music in lab or only having a few graded lab reports were such gifts. I wish, however, that the two quizzes at the beginning of the course weren't weighted so heavily! Ugh! They test like lab preparedness and lab safety, which are undoubtedly important but shouldn't count for as much as 3 EPs. Also, one general problem I had with lab is that I feel like during lab itself, I'm just following a recipe, and it's only in my preparation for lab or synthesis of the material later on that I actually learn.

I wish there were more grades, because after having a hard time with the first post-lab, it was hard to bring up my grade.

Overall, the course was by far superior to the general chemistry lab. Everyone was less stressed, creating a better learning environment.

Definitely a strength is that for the first time so far in any labs I have taken, in this lab all of the steps you take are meaningful and lead to the production of an actual product. The workload is fair. Not much on how it could be improved.
Great class; facilitated learning and was actually super interesting.

The course teaches basic lab techniques and procedures for organic chemistry. It allows you the chance to get familiar with the equipment and concepts in a hands-on setting, which is a nice experience. The labs are interesting and doable, and the professor is great. The only thing I would suggest is to have more hoods dedicated to acetone wash and organic liquid disposal!

Great teaching staff. Helpful lab staff too. This is how a lab should be and it was a MASSIVE improvement over the general chemistry lab. Laid back but with some challenges thrown in for the purpose of learning and not just busy work. I never felt like I was being asked to do something that wouldn't benefit my learning.

The class was pretty self-motivated -- you either did the work or didn't. After a year in general chemistry lab, this class was the best thing in the world. The TAs seemed to actually care about you, and no one was trying to fail you. Yet the class was of course also challenging in its own ways, and I honestly genuinely enjoyed it.
I really enjoyed the course. You have quizzes everyone in awhile that are very straight forward and the EPs aren't difficult but they are helpful.

Strengths: The whole course was very clearly laid out in the course packet, and all necessary materials were easily accessible on canvas. It was straightforward in terms of what was expected. Dr. DiMeglio is also a very generous and helpful lab director. 
Weaknesses: not very collaborative, as I think a lab could be.
One strength was that every assignment was clearly explained in terms of what was expected.

The course is well-organized to prevent excessive lab time or work outside the lab. It reinforces the concepts learned in lecture without being too lecture-heavy during class. It encourages hands-on learning that is much more engaging. A possible improvement would be three post-lab assignments instead of 3, so that each assignment would be worth less and there would be more opportunity for both improvement in preparation of the assignment and analysis of each lab.

This course was excellent in using practice and hands-on work to teach students lab techniques. It could improve if TA's instructed more in the beginning of labs about why we were doing what we were doing.
you really learn organic lab techniques in an incremental way

Strengths: Good to facilitate information from lecture - only if the lecture is ahead.
Weakness: It was difficult to find help for lab assignments

Strengths: Engaging, very helpful in learning new techniques, well organized, exciting, extremely helpful TA
Weakness: not in actual course but I would prefer if first years were the ones in lab together as they have less experience in lab and not be overwhelmed by students that took General Chemistry Lab

I felt that one weakness of the course is that almost all the points lost were based on formatting errors in project reports. In addition, much of the grading was inconsistent and varied from TA to TA.

Strength: Structure, orderly, meaningful experiments 

Weakness: Not many I can think of. IR was a bitch but that's not a fault of the course.

Strengths: 
- organized lab setting/homework assignments
- knowledgable TA's
- terrific professor
- clear feedback on assignments
Weaknesses:
- TA's are often 'left in the dark' with regard to assessments (quizzes and tests), so students can't easily ask, what to expect. They must gain access to professors.
It's perfect

The strength of the course is that students get to learn and review lab techniques that are important for lab work and research.  Also, labs often do not take the entire 4 hours, and most of the time, students can leave when they finish.  The weakness of the course is that only a few techniques are taught.  Learning a new one each week would improve the course.
Nicely organized, good for 0.5 credit
In terms of teaching style, workload and actual lab work, it was SO LUCH better than gen chem lab. Workload is alright and the labs are interesting.
Instructions are very clear. Concepts are presented clearly. Work is very straightforward. I think it's good the way it is. Maybe we could do without the quizzes.

The course is structured so that in the beginning you learn the most basic lab techniques, and by the end you are able to carry out experiments that build upon each of the learned skills, and you are able to use all of them in a single experiment. i enjoyed this format because it kept me refreshed on the skills we had previously learned, and it allowed us to practice and get better with each experiment

I think that this is a class that is determined by the TA you get. Your experience is colored by them. I didn't like my TA as much which detracted from this experience, which is unfortunate. I think that is a definite weakness of the course because having a poor TA affect grades, experiences, and honestly interest in the subject.

The strengths are the experiments we do and, by far and large, Professor DiMeglio. She is so helpful and her course packet is very thorough and detailed. The quizzes are very specific and short, which can lead to poor grades that are unfortunately worth a ton of your grade. I would suggest making the 3 quizzes longer so that missing two doesn't result in a D in your grade. Otherwise, the course is great!
The course could have been much better organized. It could have been based on laboratory techniques and chemical knowledge rather than memorization of useless facts and following nitpicky directions.

The class gives a great foundation for work in an organic chemistry lab. It introduces a lot of concepts and skills needed for lab work and the TAs and the professors were really helpful. I can't really think of any weaknesses.
This course was wonderful! Structured to fit the organic chemistry lecture and the instructions were clear with really helpful TFs.
This course is fair and wants you to learn. The final exam is very heavily weighted, which is difficult in its multiple choice format.

Great job of teaching the skills we needed and assignments that were a  REASONABLE length. 
One weakness was that grading was fairly inconsistent and the huge weight placed on only a few assignments made it a more stressful experience for many students than it needed to be.
Felt that the distribution of the work was extremely unbalanced. Sometimes, I felt like there was very little work to do, and other weeks, I felt inundated with hours of work.
strengths: very well organized. professor dimeglio was very attentive to our learning progress and did and all the TAs did a great job creating a learning environment.
It wasn't as hateful as gen chem lab.
The strengths of this course is the workload and the professor. Dr. Dimeglio focuses on the skills that are most important and the course forces you to fully understand the procedures you are doing.

The grading weights and distributions seemed weird, especially when quizzes were worth 20 points and only had 5 questions. Also, it felt like there was too much attention to formatting in the grading of the post lab assignments.
Strengths- well taught, allowed for independence, very cool course, kind teacher, about the learning, very organized, clear expectations

I think that the Course Packet for this course was extremely helpful because it explained all of the techniques being used in each experiment in a way that made it very easy to understand what would happen when we performed the experiment in lab. I think the format of the course, with the requirement of writing Experimental Plans each week before lab, was extremely helpful because it forced us to read through the procedure and understand what we would be doing prior to coming to lab and needing to perform the experiment. I also think that the TAs and Dr. DiMeglio were so approachable and helpful throughout every experiment; having them there and available to answer any question eased some of the stress of needing to perform techniques that we have never seen or used before.
Overall, I felt like this course was run very well. My TA Emily Barth was very nice, supportive, and helpful, and Dr. DiMeglio was very helpful as well.
Some strengths were independence and reasonable workload. I wish that we had covered a little bit more analysis, like NMR Spectroscopy.
This course and its experiments complemented and enhanced the materials learned in organic chemistry class.
This is a well taught course. I enjoyed the variety of labs. I would have liked to collaborate more with my peersin a real lab scientists constantly have to work together.
The class is great. The experiments are an appropriate length; you never feel rushed or pressed for time which allows you to focus on being precise and really perfecting your techniques.

I really liked how the class was structured. The workload was not too much and the material was not too hard to understand as well. I liked how we had to prepare before each lab, this made sure we really knew what was going on. The only thing I did not like about the course was the final, which was a lot tougher than any of the material we had to do throughout the semester and also graded kind of tough, with one multiple choice question worth 5 points.

I think overall the course was very well organized to facilitate both student learning and critical thinking. However, I do think the class could have been a little more strict when it came to safety and cleaning because I did see people just dispose of acid/base incorrectly or leaving the scales really dirty.

Strengths: This course was very well-organized and all the guidelines/expectations of the course are outlined in the course packet. The workload is not too excessive and definitely manageable. Christine also does a great job of getting to know all the students and will help you understand what you're doing. Overall, it was a great course and was enjoyable. Weaknesses: Grading was frustrating at times since it was so variable between TAs. Some TAs would take points off for random, trivial reasons while other TAs would just award most of their students full marks on every assignment. Just make sure to follow the EP guidelines word for word in the course packet. Also, it would've been nice if this course complemented the things we learned in the lecture course. It felt completely separate and disjointed throughout the semester.
I liked only having a few post lab assignments and it is usefull having the pla's to know what you will do in lab. The final exam was a bit too tough and multiple choice is sometimes very harsh.
Many of the labs were cool and generally active.  Learned many different techniques which was good.  Work load was also manageable.

The course provides an excellent foundation in organic chemistry lab techniques, giving students the opportunity to learn each skill and apply it in subsequent labs. It was difficult for me to jump into this course as a freshman (having not done Yale gen chem lab) and learn how to operate in a lab with no lab partner and all of the techniques at the same time. I don't think that this is a weakness of the course as much as an adjustment for me, but it defined my experience in the course all the same. I would've liked to do another lab or two with a partner, especially in the beginning of the course, because it takes time to build self-confidence with such tasks. I also made the mistake of choosing a hood next to a whiteboard and hallway, which was very isolating -- it would have helped a lot to be next to other students who I could ask questions.

There were a lot of spelling and grammatical errors in the course packet, and the wording on the quizzes was generally vague and misleading. The EPs I found to be generally helpful with understanding the experiments. The Post-Lab assignments were also a bit vague in some questions, and I think there was a lot of inconsistency in grading across the TAs. Not a bad course, especially because the experiments seemed to have a purpose to them, but the experiments could have been explained better in the lab manual or by the TAs.

I think this course does a good job of providing an introduction to some lab techniques and basic synthesis processes. It was great that each student got an individual hood and so much of the work was independent. The use of IR spectroscopy felt a little bit unnecessary because the graphs are so difficult to interpret correctly and it isn't used much by research labs.

A huge strength of this course are the mandatory EPs (prelabs). They force you to know what exactly it is that you are doing in lab and WHY. I believe this process really enhanced my experience with labs, especially after gen chem lab. Another strength of this course are the short but extremely efficient labs. You learn a lot from a short 2-hour lab and the length mentally helps you deal with weekly labs.

The class was very engaging and each lab session taught or applied interesting techniques. One weakness could be that different TA's operate very differently, so some lab periods receive informative lectures and some sections leave much earlier and are much more efficient.

TAs and professor were much more understanding and patient and evoked less stress from students compared to general chem laboratory; grading was a bit strict when it came to the EPs/pre-lab material and lab reports but apparently final grades are adjusted for stricter TAs; there were also only 2 lab reports which was fine on workload but they were heavily weighted so it would have been nice to have other more heavily weighted things so if you didn't do as well on one, you could make it up with others)

Overall, this was a very good course. There aren't any weaknesses that I can think of. The TA that I had was very friendly and helpful during lab. The whole class loved her. We had a great time talking to her, including talking about things other than chemistry. The labs each week were very straight-forward. The procedures were given to us in advance, and we just needed to write a pre-lab each week, which wasn't hard. The pre-lab was mainly summarizing the info about the lab that was already given to us in the course packet.
This course was very well organized and had interesting experiments that differed with each lab.

I thought the workload was very manageable and the course was great! Everything was very fair and the teaching scholars were very helpful. I thought we could have more postabs - I wouldn't mind more practice with scientific writing. I liked the structure of the course and found the course packet a good resource for safety and guidelines.
The course was very active (as is the nature of a lab course), but not overwhelmingly rigid, which I enjoyed and appreciated.

The strengths of this course was the fact that it promoted independence in the lab and taught lab skills through interesting experiments.  The weakness was the fact that the course relied heavily on the course packet, which was sometimes vague or unclear when it came to describing how to do the experimental plans.

A major strength of the class was a focus on learning how to do laboratory techniques as opposed to getting a very specific yield or a precise answer. This reduced stress during lab time and overall fostered greater learning. A weakness of the course was the weighting of certain assignments. I spent collectively far more time on the EPs than on the PLs yet the weighting of these assignments did not reflect this fact.

It would be nice if the course tracked more with Chem 220 rather than freshman organic chemistry; there were a few experiments whose mechanisms we didn't discuss in lecture until the week of final exams, which made it a bit difficult to follow in the pre-lab lecture and in the EP notes.
well organized course but grading was harsh, needs more grades so that one bad grade wouldn't bring overall grade down so much

This course was very well-designed. It taught me all the necessary skills, techniques, and concepts without any additional stress/ frustration. The concepts behind the labs were often intellectually stimulating and challenging, but never turned stressful.

When writing my first Post Lab Assignment, I was not sure how much detail to include when answering questions, and how to approach the questions. I lost some points for not having enough details. Perhaps there could be a little more explanation in the course packet.
The labs were very clear, and designed to help us learn.
A strength is limited lab reports and a laid back atmosphere that makes it easier to learn. However, due to the limited lab reports, the grading scheme was a little funky.
Prof DiMeglio was a strength. She was great!
A strength is that the labs were well structured and the EPs made us accountable in preparing for labs.

Strengths: very chill throughout the semester, this semester we only had 2 lab reports, Dr. DiMeglio is so sweet and caring. Weakness: the final exam wasn't a fair representation of the course-- it was only ~30 multiple choice questions, each worth 5 points. It basically determines your final grade, and I feel like it didn't reflect the content and skills that were emphasized to us throughout the course. But in defense of the final exam, I guess there has to be a way to stratify everyone's grades so letter grades can be assigned because I think most people had above a 90 in the course before the final exam.

A strength is that Dr. D carefully plans each lab such that we are eased into different lab techniques that build on each other from week to week. A weakness (although this isn't Dr. D's fault) is that if students aren't given their first choice lab they may not be able to take lab at all given the other classes they are taking. For example, Dr. D told us this semester that ~120 students put Friday lab as their first choice and there are only ~70 spots. For many of the ~50 students who didn't get Friday lab, that was the only day they could take lab, and had to endure the stress of a waitlist. Several of these students (many of whom I know personally) didn't get Friday lab, and thus had to wait until next semester to take lab. If students have to take orgo lab, they are most likely pre-med, and don't have the luxury of taking courses whenever. This is Yale. There should be a solution to this problem, especially since the increasing class sizes with the addition of the new colleges means the number of students who don't get their lab day will increase. I didn't think this would be an issue with orgo lab, since it wasn't in Gen Chem, but it was and it should be addressed.

This course was wonderful because it emphasized all the right things: safety, lab techniques, preparation, and student learning. I thought the pace was perfect, and our instructions (both verbal and written in the course packet) were very clear and helpful. I thought there was a strong prioritization of safety and neatness. The lab itself was a very pleasant environment to work and learn in.

The course could be improved by more closely tracing the organic chemistry sequence and what we were learning there. It could be an excellent exercise/practice for the normal class, and could make the normal class feel more relevant and interesting, but felt pretty separate most of the time.
Really well structured lab class-- so much better than gen chem lab!  The textbook for the lab should be recommended though, not required (I never used it once)
The prelabs are very tedious and do not seem necessary (especially the data tables).
Having a multiple choice practice exam does nothing to evaluate lab skills. A practical exam is much better suited for the course

A strength was I really feel I learned a lot and I got to solidify a lot of the methods I was taught. A weakness was that some labs seemed a little bit of a waste of time but overall MUCH better than gen Chem lab.
I liked this course; I thought the work load was manageable and there were a good number of assignments
This course really enabled me to develop my lab skills.
The lab was organized, but oftentimes collecting safety information felt like busywork.
There are very few grades in the course so if you get a low grade one one of the assignments, it is very hard to bring up your grade.
Amazing professor and well organized course with a nice build up of information. I really enjoyed this course!!
This was a good lab course. Material was explained clearly before labs, TAs and professor were helpful. Everything went smoothly.
This course was well taught and well organized but it requires the same amount of time and effort as a one credit course and should definitely count as one full credit rather than half a credit.

Strengths: Dr. DiMeglio is a great instructor who encouraged learning from your mistakes. She really boosted my confidence. The course has a reasonable workload (students prepare a 1-3 page experimental procedures per week and there are only two full lab reports). All of the experiments can be performed in 4 hours (usually less). Also, you are not graded by how well you did the procedures (i.e. yield or purity), easy final (multiple choice)

Weaknesses: Some TA's grade more harshly than others (though grades are adjusted for this in the end)
The course is very well organized and clear.
Much more independence compared to gen chem lab, and less mundane.
DiMeglio is GREAT AND SOOOO MUCH more helpful than Dr. G in genchem
The strengths of the course were teaching students about techniques organic chemists use in synthesis reactions to purify and quantify their yeild. There werent many weaknessses.
I think having multiple labs included in single lab reports made it easier to understand/visualize how they all related.

The course could offer students more opportunities to apply what they have learned to deduce what they should do in later experiments where techniques are repeated, but otherwise I was very satisfied with the course.

Strength: This was a very well-organized class, and DiMeglio walked around and was always available to help us if we had questions during lab. The pre-lab write-ups that we wrote prior to each lab were helpful in helping us understand what we were to do each week.

Weakness: n/a
Run very efficiently and thoroughly.

The course was very well organized via the course manual, grades, and deadlines from the beginning of the semester. The only thing I did not like was that grading did not seem to be uniform across different lab groups.
Great class, where the WHY is emphasized instead of the WHAT.

The strengths of this course are that Professor DiMeglio is amazing and super helpful! Every time I had a question, she was more than willing to help me and she wanted all of her students to succeed. The TAs are amazing and everyone really cares about their students. Some of the weaknesses are that the post lab assignments can be graded a little harshly and not all TAs grade the same way. Also, the final was much harder than the quizzes and I wasn't entirely sure how to prepare for it.
Lowkey this is as good as its gonna get. Wayyy better than Gen Chem lab! Freshmen (First Years, sorry), it gets better.

The experiments were easy-to-follow yet challenging, which was appreciated for such a long time block. There was also a lot of help that made the labs go very smoothly. However, a major weakness is the written final examination, as none of the material covered on the exam was lab-specific. While the lab hopes to provide a better understanding of organic chemistry in general, I do not really believe that the proper resources had been provided to allow for success on this exam. Also, much of our grading was based on organization instead of actual material.

The biggest weakeness I found in the course was the percentage of the final grade that the final was worth. Compared to all the work put in previously it accounted for a larger percentage than it should have. Further there was not a great method to study for the final besides just reviewing the course packet. However a strength of the course was the value of the course packet and how effectively it was structured . The labs also built on each other which seemed prudent.

I'd recommend this course and even considered taking the second semester of lab without taking the lecture. Seems to be somewhat TA dependent, but all-around very low-stress and lots of fun (especially in comparison to gen chem lab). I genuinely enjoyed lab each week, the workload isn't overwhelming, and you usually get out early!
Take if you are taking organic chemistry.
Yes! Dr. DiMeglio is amazing and this is a great intro lab course to take.
Would recommend. Great course for understanding organic chemistry.
Yes, if you are required to take or or think it may be beneficial in the future. Otherwise, there is not really a point in taking the class.
Required for pre-med. That's about it. Decent course; much better than gen chem lab
I would recommend this course to any student taking organic chemistry.

If you're reading this, you likely don't get a choice as to whether or not you take CHEM 222L. However, don't worry! This course is nothing like gen chem lab and you will likely enjoy it. Dr. D is very kind and makes the course very manageable and enjoyable. A lot of the course is dependent on your TA, though.
Yes! much better than gen chem lab
Not a bad lab class but somewhat hard to get a good grade in since everything is graded harshly. Also the final exam was more difficult than I thought it would be.
Definitely! I learned a lot from this course, and think it is very well organized.
Yes, it is a pretty comprehensive overview of the lab techniques that are important for first semester organic chemistry.
Not super hard, but try to stay on top of the material or you may feel overwhelmed when the written final rolls around. Dr. DiMeglio is the best and super nice though.

absolutely, especially after experiencing some of the worse lab courses, I'm happy to say that I would recommend this course for someone interested in orgo/encourage someone who's premed to at least wait until taking this course to drop out.

I would recommend it because Dr. DiMeglio is truly a delight to work with. The class is a little stressful because of how specific her expectations are, but it's definitely one of the most positive lab courses I've taken at Yale.
Yes, great learning experience.
You gotta. Not a bad lab to have to take--usually chill. Don't throw away the quizzes early on because you'll wish you had those points later.
If you hated gen chem lab, don't be afraid of this course! It is so much better! Lab is always stressful for me but this class made me less stressed and more confident.
Totally! Orgo lab was by far the best lab I have taken so far.
Yes, if you are taking CHEM 220/174 concurrently.
Yes, better than Gen Chem Lab. I doubt you have a choice though.
I would recommend this course to students who need to take a chemistry lab. The labs we do are interesting, and the teaching is good as well.
Yes. Great lab class. Not one that you have to dread each week.
If you need it!
Most people will only take Orgo and Orgo lab if they are pre-reqs and I definitely wouldn't recommend taking Orgo lecture if you don't have to but I really did enjoy the lab course!
Yes, if they are taking organic chemistry.
Yes, I thought that it provides a great introduction to organic chemistry lab techniques.

Most students take orgo lab because they have to and not because they necessarily want to--but for a class that just has that tendency, it's pretty painless! Dr. D is great and some of the labs are pretty interesting.
Yes. Besides it being a premed requirement, this class teaches valuable skills that students can take into other labs.
1000000% better than gen chem lab this course is wonderful, stress free and the dr dimeglio cares so much about you and your life and labwork

Recommend. I've heard orgo lab is wayyy easier than gen chem lab, and DiMeglio genuinely cares about you. Generally, the lab TA's are really helpful. If you're required/need to take this course for your major, definitely take it! Make sure you get to know your TA bc you'll spend most of your time with the lab TA.
I would recommend solely because it is not particularly difficult and fulfills a pre-med requirement. For those who have no interest in future lab work, this class can be rather tedious.

Yes as it would be a great way for anyone who is taking Organic Chemistry to learn new techniques required for lab as well as see the practical version of matters covered in class. It is well organized and 4 hours well spent each week.
I would recommend because, despite its weaknesses, it still provides valuable hands-on experience with organic chemistry experiments.

If you're doing Orgo, this lab course will only serve to heighten your understanding of chemical processes. You actually learn in this course unlike many others. It is not like other superfluous laboratory courses at Yale that are very hand wavey with little substance (aka PHYS165/Gen Chem). The instructor and TA want you to leave the course with practices and techniques that are actually useful. Even though some portions of the course may seem like odd (like the EP's) they are actually really helpful in allowing you to understand the WHY and WHAT of chemical processes.

Yes, I would recommend the course. For most STEM students, I believe CHEM222L is the perfectly balanced lab course. It isn't too challenging, but still teaches plenty. I believe students who take it can, more often than not, handle all the work, and still get a lot out of the course.
Yeah, it's pretty informative and pretty fun. You get to make some cool compounds and it really goes well with the orgo lecture.
Only for any requirements
I mean its never great to nix half your afternoon, so take it if you have to
It's a good lab, and you learn really good, useful techniques. All the information is presented in a clear manner.
Most students will take this course because they have to, and honestly it is a very rich course where you will learn alot. It also compliments the material in the lecture course.
This is an improvement to General Chemistry Lab, so take it!
Only if required by major or premed.

Yes, it is a great course. My only piece of advice is to study for the quizzes and do the PLs with extreme detail: they are worth a ton of your grade. This course is 10000000000000x better than gen chem lab and DiMeglio is not a tyrant like Dr. G. You will love the course. P.S.: If you get an A on the final written the exam, you get an A in the course no matter what, so study a lot for the final. Do the study questions listed at the end of each experiment.

I wouldn't recommend it unless you absolutely have to take it for your major. It's a nitpicky class. Caused me many hours in which I was just trying to follow the directions specifically when I could be actually learning something.
Yes, I think this course would be a great way to develop lab skills. I would definitely recommend this course t another student.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student!
Take it if you have to. As far as labs go, this one is pretty good.

Yes, It's a good complement to the organic chemistry lecture and honestly feels like a breeze compared to GenChem lab. Assignments are a much more reasonable length and there's ample opportunity for extra help if you need it.
Yes i think this was a great lab and I truly learned a lot.
It's so much better than the general chemistry lab. I definitely recommend it.
If you're premed then you have to take it. Otherwise don't bother.
Absolutely. Its a pre-med requirement and much better than gen chem lab.
Yes, the instructors and the coursework are very conducive to helping me learn.
Yes

I would definitely recommend this course to another student who is interested in organic chemistry in lab settings, who wants to pursue research (especially in a chemistry or organic chemistry lab), or who is interested in chemistry, organic chemistry, or the pre-med track. This course gives a nice introduction for how organic chemistry can be applied in a lab setting and for basic experiments that would be conducted in any chemistry lab.

It is a relatively lighthearted lab course where you can enjoy a great professor and relatively interesting experiments. It can get tedious doing similar things week after week but in the end you are surprised how much you actually learn.
Yes.
Well, it's required for majors and pre-med, but I don't think that it's a class taken for fun mainly because the 5 hour slot is pretty inhibiting to one's schedule.
Yes, this class was an important introduction to standard lab techniques.
Only if they are pre-med, because why?
I would recommend this course to other strong STEM or premed students. It is a requirement for many majors and for premed.

I would definitely recommend.  I feel as if a lot of students who take lab dread it because it is such a big block of time in a student's schedule. However, this class is actually enjoyable and time flies by (in a good way).

I would recommend this course. The class is fun and I had a good time. I actually looked forward to lab, which is very surprising to me. The TAs and Professor DiMeglio are all very nice and very willing to help.

It is a required course for many STEM majors and pre-meds, however if you were interested, I would highly recommend the course just because it is 100x better than general chemistry lab. The atmosphere is more laid-back and the focus is on learning lab skills as opposed to making sure every single experiment was perfectly carried out.

Yes! It was a good introduction to learning the basics of organic chemistry laboratory skills. In general, it was fun and enjoyable, and it never took up the entire 4 hoursmost people are finished by 3:30. The workload is manageable and there are only two lab reports. Christine is also incredibly nice and makes sure everyone understands what they're doing and really tries to get to know every student.
Much better than Gen Chem!!!

Orgo lab is much better than most labs.  It is not too difficult and the workload is not bad because there are only 2 real lab reports and even those are not very long.  There are weekly prelab assignments due but those also can be done in a reasonable amount of time.  The final is not too difficult if you reread the lab manual before the exam and learn what we did and what commands are used for what.  Overall one of the better and more interesting labs.
Just take it if you need to.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student -- it gave me invaluable chemistry lab experience. The labs were interesting (especially the later ones) and gave me many opportunities to practice and refine the techniques I learned.

Only as a requirement. But as far as labs go, it's not a bad one. Most experiments were done in about 2 1/2 hours, and there wasn't too much written work outside of class aside from the two Post-Lab assignments.
I would recommend this course to any student who likes methodical lab work or anyone who needs to take this class for major requirements.
I would recommend this course if you are interested in o-chem lab techniques. You will have a great instructor at your hands.
Seems like it would only be helpful for STEM majors, but if you are thinking about research in any STEM field, I think it would be a very helpful and rewarding experience.

You have to take this laboratory course with an organic chemistry course, so you can't just take this one by itself (to my knowledge), but overall, a pretty enjoyable lab course; feels like 0.5 credits instead of 1.0 like gen chem did; the latest that I ever got out of o-chem lab was around 4:15 so you never go until 5 which is nice; Dr. DiMeglio is very kind, asks about your day, plans for the weekend, if you ever need help, etc. so she made the laboratory experience much better! 

(No pre-lab lecture formally, no weekly quizzes except for maybe 3, only 2 post-lab reports, weekly experimental plans/pre-lab assignments)
I would recommend it if you need this class for your major or a pre-med requirement. It is a really good class (very well organized).
I would recommend this course to another student because it is a good introductory lab to organic chemistry
Yes! A great course if you're looking to apply concepts learned in class and become familiar with chemistry lab work.
Yes...not only is it necessary for a chemistry major, but it complements well the organic chemistry class, and is a reasonable course as concerns workload and difficulty.
Overall 222L was a fantastic class and I would readily recommend it to another student.

The course is a lot more laid back than gen chem lab but by no means is a gut. EPs (pre-lab notes) are only worth ten points, so any mistake will result in a -1, which can make it difficult to raise your course grade because there aren't too many other assignments. The experiments are interesting enough, but sometimes frustrating; you generally get out around 4:00 though. It seemed to me that the lab follows freshman organic chemistry more closely than Chem 220, because a few of the experiments expected us to be familiar with mechanisms that we had not covered at that point in the semester in 220. The final exam was also a bit tough, especially with each question being worth 5 points (all multiple choice, so no partial credit).
Yes, mandatory for premeds and many science majors

If you already went through gen chem lab, then take the orgo lab! Orgo lab is so much better than gen chem lab for many, many reasons. Unlike gen chem, in orgo lab you can get everything done before the 5pm deadline--actually, you will found yourself getting out of lab way before 4pm. The labs are intellectually stimulating, and they are really fun. You are not graded on your yield, so you don't feel pressured to make no mistakes. In fact, mistakes are allowed and what makes you learn in this class. Definitely take it!
Yes, this lab was both fun and informative.
Yes!
Great course! Its likely required, but still not bad. Prof DiMeglio is a gem.
Yes, the professor is so nice and you learn a lot.
Yes, it's more chill than gen chem lab

If you're taking this, you probably have to. But it's much better than Gen Chem, and Dr. D is great. You will learn a lot, and not feel like lab is pointless to go to every week (looking at you, Gen Chem). Also, you'll probably get out around 3:30-4 every week.

I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn organic lab techniques. The course instructors really care that you learn, and you learn through a methodical, systematic approach that emphasizes safety and clarity, with the result that you learn the material well and really enjoy the elegance of the chemistry.
This lab course is actually pretty interesting and fun. Take it if you're taking orgo for sure.

So much better than gen chem lab-- there aren't weekly quizzes or pre lab lectures so you just get to lab and then do the experiment and leave so much earlier.  The textbook was kinda useless-- im glad i didn't even buy it because you really didn't need to read it.
Yes, best lab Ive taken so far!
This course provides a good introduction to the major organic chemistry lab techniques
I would. Once you get into the swing of the EPs, the course is quite fun and helped at some points in the lecture.
Yes pretty good lab not hugely useless work Professor is an absolute gem defiantly a decent course.

Yes, though a lot of bio and STEM majors have to take this course to fulfill their major requirements. I personally thought the workload could be a bit tough sometimes, but I do think Dr. DiMeglio does her best to make the course as enjoyable as possible. Some TAs do a better job of teaching course concepts than others. I found reading the course packet to be crucial to prepare for the final and to understand what was going in in the course overall.
Not unless required
Yes.
It is good for learning how to perform lab techniques, but you will not feel too intellectually stimulated.
If you need it take it.
Yes!!! It was a really nice introduction to many orgo lab techniques.
If you must take orgo lab, this is a good course that you will enjoy and is not too stressful.
You probably don't have a choice to take this course or not, but taking it the same semester as orgo 1 will definitely enhance your learning and your understanding of orgo.
The course was engaging and I would reccomend it.
Yes! This is a good course for either fulfilling a SC credit or simply as a prereq. (or if you just like chemistry a lot)
Sure, much less stressful course than the previous years lab.
I definitely would recommend this course. Its a good way to learn how the material learned in class is applied in lab and real life scenarios.
Yes, to students looking to continue studying organic chemistry I believe the lab accentuates the lecture very well.
Yes. Pre med students take it!
Yes because it provides a good foundation in organic chemistry lab techniques
Yes, I would definitely recommend this class! The expectations were clear and was way better than Gen Chem Lab. DiMeglio is also very happy to help and give advice during lab.
Yes, it's great practice for basic chem lab techniques.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. I was able to learn a lot from this course, and the workload was manageable.
I'd take this course if you're required to take the course.

I would recommend this course to another student because the teaching staff really care about their students and want them to do well. It is really easy to get help and be able to succeed in this course.
Yeah, as far as labs go, this one is not that bad! It's not fascinating or anything, but the workload is actually manageable unlike gen chem.
I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to try a lab course, as it has a great support base to allow for a lot of learning.

For a wet lab this course seems like a great place to start as I didnt not feel like I was missing anything even though it was my first lab. However no one should take this unless its required for their major as it does feel like it takes up a decent amount of time
